title: How to know the truth about something when someone disagrees with you - Quora

response.answer_text: There has always been a difference between “the truth” and “a truth” For instance you are driving your car and suddenly you experience the balance wobbly, you realize “a truth” that you have a flat and your journey ruined. But the moment you spot a Mechanic, your realization of “a truth” becomes false, as the mechanic can easily fix the situation and you would again be set for your journey. This holds true for every instance in the materialistic world, take any example. Which is the reason why its said “ihamuna sukhiyimpa”, “everything connected with the material world is momentary pleasurable and can turn table any moment” “The Truth” is that fact which withstands the test of time and never changes. “Dharmo Rakhshati Rakshitah[1]”, “Satyamev Jayate[2]” “Ahimsa paramo Dharma, Dharma himsa tathaiva cha[3]” are few examples, There are countless facts leading to the same single Truth (i.e the supreme energy). So when you ask “How do you know the truth about something when someone disagrees with you”, it only means that you do not know “the Truth” and hence are confused. To change your position from such state you need to practice, the knowledge of which comes at a cost not negotiable via money. Footnotes[1] Vartul Pandey's answer to What is the true meaning of the shlok Dharmo Rakshati Rakshitah?[2] Pranjal Pathak's answer to What is the meaning of the phrase 'Satyamev Jayate'?[3] Sachin Pandey's answer to If Sanatan Dharma is built on the principle of "ahimsa paramo dharma" i.e Non-Violence, then why is there violence in the Mahabharata and the Ramayana? What is the real definition of ahimsa in Sanatan Dharma?

author_info.name: Keinosuke Johan Miyanaga / 宮永 ヨハン 計之介

response.answer_text: What you now know is that you never knew the truth, if all it took to doubt yourself was someone disagreeing with you. A fact is a statement backed by evidence. Either it’s backed or it isn’t. Either the evidence is accurate or it isn’t. A fact has nothing to do with what anyone thinks about anything. Let’s say you’re 5′11. It doesn’t matter what anyone says, not even you. If you’re 5′11 you are 5′11, and either you know it or you don’t. You either measured it yourself or you didn’t. You used accurate tools or you didn’t. You measured it recently or you didn’t. But none of the variables makes your height not a fact, or the height that you know completely false. Either you know a fact or you don’t. You either know the accuracy of what you know or you don’t. The same applies with whether your car needs gas. Or whether you’re out of milk. Or whether you’re late for your appointment. Or whether you did your homework. These are simple facts. They are simple facts, because the evidence that backs them is simple also. An opinion is a statement backed by a person. Opinions are always right. The fact that “you thought something” or “felt something” or “believe in something” are all true, so long as you are honest. But because we make up our opinions freely, they are often factually incorrect. They can even be impossible to factually test. This makes opinions contradict easily. But we’re still all entitled to our opinions. Therefore, we only have a problem when we decide we must agree. We only have a problem when we disagree with someone else’s opinion. But the moment you do this, the only basis for you to be correct is either your opinion — in which case you’re just pulling the higher moral authority card — or facts — in which case you are suggesting there is valid evidence. In the case of the former, they will usually fight back, unless they love you enough not to. In the case of the latter, and in the case that there was true evidence, then what you held was never an opinion to begin with. Which makes you a confused person if you did not know that. And, which also still does not make you correct, unless the other person believes in facts. Yes, you can be scientifically correct, and yet perfectly good, smart, fun loving people will completely disagree with you and may even make you eat dirt. Why? Because everyone is entitled to their opinion. But everyone is not entitled to their facts. And everyone that puts milk on their grocery list when they are out of milk does practice this. So in the end, they’re just being smart with you, and you with them, if you’re returning the favor by arguing over facts. You either have evidence or you don’t. It’s either accurate or it isn’t. And either you can read the evidence properly or you can’t. There is nothing to argue over. There is only agreement of knowledge, or admitting you do not know. If you do not know, you could look it up. Do some digging. Go look for yourself. And that’s something you cannot do while arguing.

Are you assuming that you have the truth unless someone disagrees with you? WHen you have a view, there’s no particular reason to believe it unless there’s some access to information that you and only you have. Otherwise, it’s just someone’s opinion that you know about. If you believe that there are people smarter than you with divergent views you have some reason to suspect you’re wrong. So, then you begin the process that all ideas should take, gathering a wide range of information over time, looking at the different takes on it, the vest interpretations you can find, looking at the pros and cons of them, trying to locate and filter out biases and self-delusions, then tentatively assessing where the weight of evidence and argument leads. This is best done through many discussions with others, not just in personal reflection.

IF you disagree about a fact, it is easy to check go to Wikipedia ! If you argue about how to move on business wise or how to plan a holiday together, there is not real right or wrong. Business problems may be solved with the help of a moderator or an external force. In a holiday or marriage situation you partner has desires too and I take it into consideration and do for her things I do not fancy so much as she does for me. A disagreement may bring a new information into the situation, so a seldom brush it down.
